facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 374 of 1956 was filed by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 19, 1955, of the Assam High Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 374 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 19, 1955, of the Assam High Court in Revenue Appeal No. 33 M  of 1955.

facts.text: The appeal arises out of Assam High Court proceedings in Revenue Appeal No. 33 M of 1955 and Civil Rule No. 76 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal with special leave arises out of a judgment of the Assam High Court in Revenue Appeal No. 33  M  of 1955 and Civil Rule No. 76 of 1955.

facts.text: State of Assam (respondent No. 3) settled Charduar Brahmaputra Fishery with respondent No. 1 for three years from April 1, 1954, to March 31, 1957, at annual zama of Rs. 19,600 under r. 12 of Fishery Rules.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Assam, respondent No. 3, had settled the Charduar Brahmaputra Fishery with the respondent No. I for a period of three years, viz., from April 1, 1954, to March 31, 1957, at an annual zama of Rs. 19,600 Under r. 12 of the Fishery Rules.

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner of Darrang (respondent No. 2) received reports against respondent No. 1 alleging violation of cl. VI of the Fishery lease and other conditions.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Commissioner of Darrang, respondent No. 2, received some reports against the respondent No. 1 alleging violation of cl. VI of the Fishery lease and also of certain other companyditions of the lease.

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner obtained reports from Sub-Deputy Collector and Extra Assistant Commissioner regarding the allegations.

anchor.surface_text: He obtained reports from the Sub -Deputy Collector and the Extra Assistant Commissioner in regard to these allegations

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner concluded that respondent No. 1 created under-lease in favour of certain persons and cancelled the settlement.

anchor.surface_text: and came to the companyclusion that respondent No. 1 had created under-lease in favour of certain persons and cancelled the settlement of the fishery.

facts.text: State of Assam settled the fishery with the appellant effective from May 4, 1955, and directed respondent No. 1 to give up possession from that date.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that after such cancellation, respondent No. 3, purporting to act again under r. 12, settled the said fishery with the appellant with effect from May 4, 1955, and respondent No. 1 was directed to give up possession thereof with effect from that date.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 obtained a Rule from Assam High Court alleging the settlement with appellant was illegal.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 thereupon obtained a Rule from the Assam High Court alleging that the said settlement was absolutely illegal and the fishery had to be settled pro- perly according to the rules

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 filed Revenue Appeal against order of respondent No. 2 under rule 11 of section 1 of Fishery Rules.

anchor.surface_text: A Revenue Appeal was also filed against the order of respondent No. 2 under rule 11 of section 1 of the Fishery Rules and both the Rule and the Revenue Appeal were heard together

facts.text: Assam High Court on August 31, 1955, in Civil Rule No. 56 of 1955, Nuruddin Ahmed v. State of Assam, declared r. 12 of Fishery Rules ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court had already on August 31, 1955, delivered a judgment in Civil Rule NO. 56 of 1955, Nuruddin Ahmed v. State of Assam  1 , declaring r. 12 of the Fishery Rules ultra vires the State Government and therefore invalid and unenforceable.

facts.text: Assam High Court followed prior judgment, held respondent No. 3 lacked jurisdiction to settle under r.12 with respondent No. 1, upheld cancellation order.

anchor.surface_text: It followed that judgment and held that the respondent No. 3 had numberjurisdiction to make a settlement under  r. 12 of the Fishery Rules with the respondent No. I and the order of cancellation should be upheld on that ground alone.

facts.text: Assam High Court held settlement with appellant without jurisdiction, made Rule absolute, set aside both settlements, directed fresh settlement.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the appellant also the High Court came to the same companyclusion and held that the settlement made by respondent No. 3 in his favour was entirely without jurisdiction. The Rule obtained by respondent No. I was accordingly made absolute.

facts.text: State of Assam did not obtain leave to appeal against High Court decision in Nuruddin Ahmed v. State of Assam.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Assam had number obtained any leave to appeal against the decision of the High Court in Nuruddin Ahmed v. State of Assam  1 , and was apparently companytent with the decision that r. 12 of the Fishery Rules was ultra vires.

facts.text: Appellant obtained special leave to appeal to Supreme Court against High Court decision setting aside his settlement.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, however, obtained special leave to appeal against the decision of the High Court -which set aside the settlement of the Fishery made by respondent No. 3 along with him

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on January 29, 1957, by BHAGWATI J.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. January 29. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BHAGWATI J.-This appeal with special leave arises out of a judgment of the Assam High Court

facts.text: State of Assam as respondent No. 3 supported appellant's position that r.12 is intra vires.

anchor.surface_text: in so far as it was added as respondent No. 3 in this appeal it took up the position that r. 12 of the Fishery Rules was intra vires, a position which it had number so far chosen to sustain

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 supported High Court judgment that r.12 is ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1, therefore, at the hearing of the appeal adopted the peculiar attitude of supporting the judgment of the High Court and of companytending that r. 12 of the Fishery Rules was ultra vires.

facts.text: Supreme Court held r.12 intra vires, declared settlement with appellant valid and operative.

anchor.surface_text: The result, therefore, is that this appeal will be allowed and the settlement of fishery rights by respondent No. 3 with the appellant declared valid and operative.

facts.text: Supreme Court noted questions of fact involved in whether respondent No. 1's lease was validly cancelled by respondent No. 2.

anchor.surface_text: Logically enough respondent No. 1 also would have been entitled to a similar relief but there are various questions of fact involved in the determination of the question whether the fishery lease in his favour was validly cancelled by respondent No. 2.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 disclaimed benefits by contending r.12 ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. I moreover has disclaimed such benefits by adopting the companytention that r. 12 of the fishery rights was ultra vires.

facts.text: Fishery settled under Chapter X of Assam Land Revenue Manual, Vol. I (6th ed.), Rules for settlement of fisheries.

anchor.surface_text: This rule occurs in chapter X of the Assam Land Revenue Manual, Vol. I  6th ed.  headed Rules for settlement of fisheries .

facts.text: Normal procedure for settlement of fisheries is by auction sales under r.3 of Section I.

anchor.surface_text: The numbermal procedure for settlement of fisheries prescribed in r. 3 of s. I is by auction sales in regard to all registered fisheries held under leases expiring on the last day of the current year

facts.text: Provision for appeal to Assam High Court against orders of Deputy Commissioner or Sub-Divisional Officer under r.11.

anchor.surface_text: provision is made in r. 1 1 for appeal to the Assam High Court against all orders of a Deputy Commissioner or Sub-Divisional Officer passed under the rules

facts.text: No appeal against order of settlement by State Government under r.12.

anchor.surface_text: and it is provided that there shall be numberappeal against an order of settlement passed by the State Government under r. 12.

facts.text: Assam High Court judgment referenced as A.I.R. 1956 Assam 48.

anchor.surface_text: under A.I.R. 1956 Assam 48. r. 12 of the Fishery Rules with the respondent No. I and the order of cancellation should be upheld on that ground alone.
This appeal with special leave arises out of a judgment of the Assam High Court in Revenue Appeal No. 33  M  of 1955 and Civil Rule No. 76 of 1955.

The State of Assam, respondent No. 3, had settled the Charduar Brahmaputra Fishery with the respondent No. I for a period of three years, viz., from April 1, 1954, to March 31, 1957, at an annual zama of Rs. 19,600 Under r. 12 of the Fishery Rules.

concepts.unlisted_description: No fishery shall be settled otherwise than by sale except by the State Government. The order of settlement passed by the State Government shall be final. Provided that the State Government may introduce the tender system of settlement of fisheries in place of sale by auction system whenever it is considered necessary.

anchor.surface_text: Section 16. Right of fishery.- The Deputy Commissioner, with the previous sanction of the Provincial Government, may, by proclamation published in the prescribed manner, declare any collection of water, running or still, to be a fishery and no right in any fishery so declared shall be deemed to have been acquired by the public or any person, either before or after the commencement of this Regulation, except as provided in the Rules made under section 155

concepts.interpretation: absolutely nothing in the provisions of s. 16 which would go to show what are the principles on which such rules [...] have to be made nor is there anything therein to indicate any policy which has to guide the State Government

anchor.surface_text: Section 155. Additional power to make rules. The Provincial Government may, in addition to the other matters for which he is empowered by this Regulation to make rules, consistent with this regulation, relating to the following matters [...] the granting of licences, or the farming of the right to fish in fisheries proclaimed under section 16

issues.text: The issue which was contested between the appellant, respondent No. 3 and respondent No. 1 as to the intra vires character of r. 12 of the Fishery Rules

anchor.surface_text: The issue which was, therefore, contested between the appellant supported as he was by respondent No. 3, the State of Assam. and respondent No. I was as to the intra vires character of 12 of the Fishery Rules.

issues.text: whether there is any power conferred on the State Government by these rules to settle fisheries otherwise than by sale, e.g., by individual settlements without a settlement thereof by auction system or by tender system

anchor.surface_text: The question, therefore, which arises for our determination is whether there is any power conferred on the State Government by these rules to settle fisheries otherwise than by sale, e.g., by individual settlements without a settlement thereof by auction system or by tender system.

State of Assam  1  or in the present case but which it tried to support as it were by the back-door by appearing in this appeal and supporting the appellant. Respondent No. 1 appears to have been in a similar quandary. If the appellant gained his point and had it established that the rule was intra vires the settlement of the fishery by respondent No. 3 with respondent No. I would have been with jurisdiction and the cancellation by respondent No. 2 would have been void and inoperative. This relief was, however, number A. 1. R. 1956 Assam 48.
